p: MAYV is thought to be principally transmitted by the bite of diurnal canopy-dwelling mosquitoes of the genus Haemagogus [ 4]. These mosquitoes are responsible for maintaining the sylvatic cycle involving nonhuman primates and birds as primary and secondary hosts, respectively. Human infections are sporadic, likely because Haemagogus spp. rarely display anthropophilic behaviors, and they possess a preference for rural areas with proximity to forests [ 12]. Vector competence (VC) studies demonstrated that anthropophilic and urban-adapted species, such as Aedes aegypti (Linnaeus, 1762) and Ae. albopictus (Skuse, 1895), are competent vectors for MAYV in laboratory conditions [ 13â€“ 15]. Culex quinquefasciatus mosquitoes positive for MAYV have also been identified from field collections during a DENV outbreak in Mato Groso County, Brazil [ 16]; however, their capacity to transmit MAYV has not been demonstrated.
